page.title: 03Pilsey Island
page.content: Pilsey Island is connected to Thorney by a causeway and West Pilsey, a narrow isthmus of hard rocks with between it and the island an area of wet sand, having crops of sea lavender, samphire & bladderwort, with marram on the highest sands. This is covered at high tide and is a feeding ground for dunlin, snipe, plover, etc. The island, recently acquired by the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds, consists mainly of rough grass and an area of gorseland. Rabbits and birds, such as stonechats and larks, inhabit this part, the seabirds nest on the tideline. Part of the grassland is used as a testing ground for paints and preparations by the Ministry of Defence. Many birdwatchers come here and there is a good anchorage for yachts on the E. of the island.
